intro: Setaria italica var. germanica, commonly known as German millet, is a small-grained cereal plant native to Europe. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and compact spikelets that bear small, hard seeds. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soils. It is drought-tolerant and often cultivated as a forage crop or for seed production. The seeds are rich in carbohydrates and have been used historically in human and animal diets.
